factoid: Prince Andrew had reached the front line.
Prince Andrew rode along the front line.
The front line of ours and the front line of the enemy were far apart on the right and left flanks.
In the center where men with a flag of truce had passed that morning, the lines were so near together that men could see each other's faces and speak to each other.
Besides the soldiers who formed the picket line on either side, there were many curious onlookers who, jesting and laughing, stared at the strange foreign enemies.
Since early morning, despite an injunction not to approach the picket line, the officers had been unable to keep sight-seers away.
The soldiers forming the picket line, like showmen exhibiting a curiosity, no longer looked at the French but paid attention to the sight-seers and grew weary while waiting to be relieved.
Prince Andrew halted to look at the French.
One soldier pointed to a Russian musketeer who had gone up to the picket line with an officer and was rapidly and excitedly talking to a French grenadier.
Sídorov was considered an adept at French.
The soldier to whom the laughers referred was Dólokhov.
Prince Andrew recognized Dólokhov.
Prince Andrew stopped to listen to what Dólokhov was saying.
Dólokhov had come from the left flank where Dólokhov's regiment was stationed, with Dólokhov's captain.
Dólokhov did not answer Dólokhov's captain.
Dólokhov had been drawn into a hot dispute with the French grenadier.
Dólokhov and the French grenadier were talking about the campaign.
The Frenchman, confusing the Austrians with the Russians, was trying to prove that the Russians had surrendered and had fled all the way from Ulm.
Dólokhov maintained that the Russians had not surrendered but had beaten the French.
Dólokhov said, 'We have orders to drive you off here, and we shall drive you off.'
The French grenadier said, 'Only take care you and your Cossacks are not all captured!'
The French onlookers and listeners laughed.
Dólokhov said, 'We'll make you dance as we did under Suvórov...'
A Frenchman asked, 'Qu'est-ce qu'il chante?'
Another Frenchman said, 'It's ancient history,' guessing that it referred to a former war.
Another Frenchman said, 'The Emperor will teach your Suvara as he has taught the others...'
Dólokhov began to say, 'Bonaparte...' but the Frenchman interrupted him.
The Frenchman said, 'Not Bonaparte. He is the Emperor! Sacré nom...'
The Frenchman said, 'The devil skin your Emperor.'
Dólokhov swore at the Frenchman in coarse soldier’s Russian and shouldered Dólokhov's musket and walked away.
Dólokhov said to Dólokhov's captain, 'Let us go, Iván Lukích.'
The picket soldiers said, 'Ah, that's the way to talk French.'
The picket soldiers said, 'Now, Sídorov, you have a try!'
Sídorov turned to the French, winked, and began to jabber meaningless sounds very fast: 'Kari, mala, tafa, safi, muter, Kaská,' he said, trying to give an expressive intonation to his voice.
Peals of healthy and good-humored laughter from the soldiers infected the French involuntarily.
The only thing left to do seemed to be to unload the muskets, explode the ammunition, and all return home as quickly as possible.
The guns remained loaded.
The loopholes in blockhouses and entrenchments looked out just as menacingly.
The unlimbered cannon confronted one another as before.
